etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Reports of the British Association for the Advancement of Science. From scientific Latin ambiens, use as noun (short for musculus ambiens) of classical Latin ambient-, ambiēns, present participle of ambīre to go about

definitions: In certain birds: a muscle in the upper leg that is connected by tendons to a muscle that bends the toes, such that bending of the legs on perching causes the toes to grip the perch. More fully "ambiens muscle".
